user_request: A Christmas poem about the magic of the season and family togetherness.

revision_history.draft:
The ornament’s weight hangs between us—  
a silent pendulum of years,  
its metal cool against your palm,  
a relic of hands that came before.  

Steam from your mug curls into the window’s frost,  
a breath held in glass,  
fogging the edge of your reflection  
until you’re both there,  
blurred and whole.  

Pine resin and cinnamon blur,  
two ghosts in the same breath—  
the scent of a fire that wasn’t ours,  
yet lingers, stubborn,  
on the wool of your scarf.  

Light fractures through icicles,  
a thousand fractured memories  
spilling into the room—  
each shard a flicker,  
a pause,  
a quiet yes.  

We hold the cold,  
and in it,  
the shape of what we’ve kept.

final_poem:
The ornament’s weight hangs between us—  
a silent pendulum, years suspended,  
its metal cool against your palm,  
a relic of hands that came before.  

Steam from your mug curls into the window’s frost,  
a breath held in glass, fogging your reflection  
until you’re both there—  
blurred and whole,  
a shared exhale.  

Pine resin and cinnamon blur,  
two ghosts in the same breath—  
the scent of a fire that never was ours,  
yet lingers, stubborn,  
on the wool of your scarf.  

Light fractures through icicles,  
a thousand memories, shattered  
into the room—  
each shard a flicker,  
a pause,  
a quiet yes.  

We hold the cold,  
and in it,  
the shape of what we’ve kept.
